On Sun, 06 Jun 2004 21:59:46 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> I think most NEAT implementations perform only one structural mutation
> at a time. 

It would be a good time to clarify this.  If your add connection
mutation rate is 0.02 and you've got 100 individuals, and there are
100,000 possible places for a new connection to be added, there should
be a total of 2,000 new connections added.  Are you saying that only
100 should be added, one for each individual?  And that if an
individual has already had a connection added, then no add node
mutations are allowed to act upon it (or vice versa if your add node
mutation operators are carried out first)?

This is not my understanding of how NEAT works.  Ken?

> As Ken already pointed out, in the gene's new context it may as well be
> a 'glob' of junk. 

Well, okay.  Then I'm still trying to figure out how it's logically
different from a mutation, or series of mutations, at that point.

> Now I realise that some may think that I've argued myself into a corner
> here, since this could be interpreted to be the opposite of my above
> argument about multiple mutations being very unlikely to be good. 

Well, yes.  I don't see how you can argue that inserting a gene into
an entirely new context is really any different than a large-scale
mutation.  They essentially have the same chance of adding to fitness,
right?

Derek
